title: Why did spices become very important commodities in the 1600s? - Quora

response.answer_text: Spices have always been important, both as a preservative and as a flavour enhancer. It appears that early man used spices in cooking, far more tthan previously thought. The reason there was such a boom in the spice trade in the 15th and 16th centuries was the so-called Age of Discovery, where Europeans sailed around the world, cataloguing geography, animals, peoples and plants. New spices were found (new to the Europeans) and traded worldwide. Spices that had previously been rare or difficult to transport suddenly became easier and more profitable. Spices like pepper and nutmeg, formerly so valuable you could trade small quantities for land (look up 'peppercorn rent') became more readily available, and trade wars were fought over them.

Spices had always been important and had always been traded.  But by 1492, when Columbus sailed, two things had happened: a) Western Europe had become more prosperous and wanted more spices. b) The Islamic world controlled the trade routes and was charging high prices,
